review_title: Solid benefits and very flexible, but still a corporation
pros: Benefits! Everyone knows about Starbucks' benefit package — it is all-encompassing and far-reaching. Flexible hours. Great for students and part-time workers with busy lives and other commitments. Pay rate. Over the last two years, the rate of pay has dramatically increased, so the base rate (in Canada at least) is above minimum wage.
cons: Customer service. This job is definitely customer service and front-facing, so you get all the challenges that come with that. Starbucks has created a "customer is always right" culture that allows for a lot of abuse and negative experiences. Union-busting. Starbucks hates unions and does not support them. Partners (employees) are always encouraged to share their thoughts/recommendations, but only within the confines of what they want to change.

cons: They are usually understaffed, they prioritize customer interaction scores while expecting fast delivery times, while you might be one of three workers pulling doubles. pros:
Got a good amount of hours, more than I honestly wanted at the time.
Got to drink as many things as you want while on the clock and experiment with drinks. 
Free meal benefit during COVID. My shift supervisors at my store didn't say anything if we ate more than our one allowed free food item.
cons:
A lot of times the people who wanted a ton of hours were promised them and never got them. Tons of turnover. Creepy male regulars. LOW LOW LOWWWWWW PAY. Lower than any other fast food place (and yes, Starbucks is fast food). They will tell you they pay above minimum wage, but "above minimum wage" for me and others there meant literally 2 cents above minimum. It was a fine job to work for a few months. 

I quit after I complained that my only 10 minute break during a 5.75 hour weekend shift would have to be taken in my first 45 minutes there due to 'business needs' and my manager told me I should be grateful that I even get a break because Starbucks isn't legally required to provide one. So I walked out. Hope you had fun calling in a replacement on a holiday weekend!

job_title: Deck Swabber / whipping boy in Santa Fe, NM
pros: Free food, but you might not get a moment to buy it, especially when closing.
cons: Predatory hiring practices pay workers low and promise to increase, only to have no solid plan or communication for this. I was promised $15/hr in the summer, and never was bumped up. Sanitizer and supplied soap will destroy your hands. My hands had rashes for over 3 months, and never did the manager attempt to make working around it easier. Since these were open wounds I had to wear gloves which only made it worse. Employees will most likely be females in the age range of 17-25. If you are not an openly gay man, you will get discriminated against at one point or another. By discrimination I mean shift leads will be females, will shovel all the physical work onto you (morning stock and inventory, swabbing the floors, cleanplay, cleaning bathrooms), meanwhile they will just lolly gag on their phones or talk with other female /gay male employees. With the other hand I was asked to walk these ladies back to their cars to fend off homeless people that harass them. When my mother had covid and I refused to stay 3 more hours and close one night, and then I was pretty much blacklisted from promotions, or any good recommendation because this was seen as an unwritten violation somehow . I would rather leave to make sure my mom was taken care of in the hospital. After this I asked to be put on part time, my hours were then cut to 9 hours or less a week, all cleanplay and closing shifts. I watched as the people I was hired with received full hours, promotions to shift lead (earlier than was allowed), and promotion to trainer. Then I also had seen people hired after me get the same treatment, not a coincidence. Many more cons, but just avoid this place, or quit when you find something better.

pros:
-flexible schedule
-good about providing time off
-supportive coworkers
-generally inclusive
-good benefits
cons: The biggest cons have been due to the turnover in executive management. I've had two store managers both of whom have been fantastic however, they have quite a few limitations. One of my biggest consistent complaints has been that we're expected to do too much with too few people. Sometimes this isn't managment"s fault (call offs), but others their are plenty of people at my store who want and are asking for more hours, but are being told are store can't afford it despite having the highest sales in our district (which is highly populated and busy) and some of the highest in the country. Despite having the people we work with and see on a day to day basis be supportive and kind. Due to Starbucks commitment to "serve all customers" we often have to put up with abuse. While I think things have gotten better in the last couple months even as a part time employee at least once a week without fail I find someone crying or having a panic attack in the freezer. It's not awful, but it's still costumer service.

review_title: I can see why many people have worked for Starbucks for a season of life
pros:
The benefits are nice. You only need to average working 20 hours a week to be eligible for insurance benefits. You also receive free drinks, food items, and discounts.
The work flow (daily duties, expectations, and tasks) is consistent throughout the company. Each store may have slight variations, but it is overall consistent. One benefit of this is being able to work at any other Starbucks location without additional training.
There are a lot of opportunities to grow and develop within the company. 
Connecting with customers and other partners is my personal favorite part of the job. You tend to see many of the same customers every day and build relationships with them. Starbucks promotes a community atmosphere that gives customers and partners a sense of belonging.
cons:
The job can be physically and socially exhausting.
The job is fast-paced and there is always a lot to be done, which can be stressful. 
A barista's wage would be hard to live on.

pros: I worked at Starbucks for years as a barista, coffee master, and trainer. Some locations I worked at (cafe only) had amazing environments and an overall positive experience.
cons:
Drive-thru locations are rigid and treat their baristas like machines. They care less and less about their well-being and more and more about the bottom line. Numbers, times, cash flow, etc. Management in my area doesn't listen to baristas, they treat the position like a revolving door. They'll find a way to fire you if you give them any reason to doubt your performance. They don't work with you or even comply with their own policies around disability and equality. 

Starbucks, as a whole, is such a hypocritical company. There are good stores and store managers out there, I'm sure, but they're closing cafe-only stores left and right. Anticipate being a fast-food worker, not a barista, because that's exactly where this company is heading.

pros: They are willing to hire people with no work experience, so good first job in that respect.
cons: Working at Starbucks was my worst job to date. There were many relationships amongst staff that were highly inappropriate, I had shift managers asking me to come to their homes for a night as an 18 year old. When I was being bullied at the store I worked at by other staff, the managers were highly unsympathetic, and even joined in to worsen the already hostile environment. I felt genuinely anxious to go to work every day and looking back, can clearly see what a horrible work environment it was. I would not recommend it to anyone, particularly the eubank and candelaria location, though I've heard similar stories from almost every location in Albuquerque.

cons: It can be a physically and emotionally strenuous job for physically disabled folk, and it can be hard to maintain a good work-life balance because of the hours on your feet working. But I had an excellent manager that really accommodated my needs.

Rushes can last hours including drinks with 5-10 customizations per drink then the customers whine about "oh it takes so long for a drink here." "Where's my drink" "where's my food" Well gee Jim/Sydney (placeholder names) maybe if you didn't order 6 Frappuccinos with an ungodly amount of add-ons or several iced white mochas with sweet cream cold foam and extra caramel drizzle, MAYBE we could get the drinks out in a minute or less like our drive times try to force us to while also pressuring us into awkward forced social interactions at the window talking to people who most of the time don't want to talk to us either :) thanks for coming to my Ted Talk.

pros: You get free coffee and food once a day. A great place to meet other gay people.
cons: To keep it short: baristas always come last, management is not consistent, and there is no uniformity in how stores are run because of poor corporate management. Quality and cleanliness is forgotten for the sake of ease or drive-thru times. Coffee knowledge has been lost as blended and heavily customized drinks take over. The company claims to care about partners and social issues but will talk-down to and infantilize baristas consistently. Retail and corporate managers can never learn when to accept mistakes. Every decision the company makes is reactionary (wage increases, supporting #BLM, bathroom access, etc.) instead of being planned out in advance to allow baristas to truly thrive. The mission and values of the company are ignored daily as managers allow baristas (and even customers, too) to get berated and work harder than ever before as they continue to make record profits and don't reword or thank their baristas for it.

pros: Good benefits and it's the kind of job that you can get out of it what you put it. There are also some opportunities if you're into art, business, or marketing to get some experience if you're creative and ask.
cons: The pay is just not enough. We're expected to create an entire experience for customers, which I really do enjoy doing, but the pay is not a living wage. I'm a supervisor and often go into overtime but I have to have roommates to survive. There is also a bit of a toxic culture when it comes to advancing and you have to constantly have your personality torn apart to get ahead. I was going to become a manager but felt I would have to become someone else in order to meet corporate's ideals. I also have watched so many managers burn out from trying to meet the expectations. Further, it's the type of culture where the harder you work, the tougher they are on you, and if you're there to skirt by and barely work, you'll never get fired unless you break actual policies, in which case you're fired too easily. Also, my schedule was impossible to keep up on because of my open availability. I was opening and closing for months until I finally burned out from not having a sleep schedule.

review_title: Good job but not a career
pros:
The pay is pretty reasonable for the requirements of the job.
If you take the job seriously, you can get valuable experience managing others as a shift supervisor. They offer good benefits given the fact that they really only hire part time. It's fast paced and you get great interactions with the regular customers. They are everywhere so you can always transfer to a new location if you have to move.
cons: This isn't really a career job unless you want to become a store manager. It isn't suppose to be a full time job, which means shifts are going to get on average 30-35 hours and baristas will average from 20-25 hours. I personally didn't like the political side of Starbucks because I didn't feel like it was relevant to how I did my job. Most importantly, the job was as good as your coworkers, and thus good coworkers made the job great and bad coworkers made it frustrating.

review_title: They don't care much and upper management is a joke.
pros:
Good benefits. 
I feel like that's about it, though to some they don't apply and cab be outdated.
cons:
Most managers aren't trained correctly
Covid messed up a lot
Retention is low so if you're there for a long run you'll most likely go through a lot of stress with entire brand new teams at once. Pay is a joke. Upper management makes horrible calls. My store was heald open cause we were a "pillar store." Without a manager for months on end while others were shut down. Months of working with 2-3 people on the floor. Dm constantly came in and acted like they cared but would constantly tell us to not take it to seriously. Dm also told me to nor worry about quasa/health violations to much but told me to crack down on dress code WHILE OUR LOBBY WAS CLOSED. Most assistant managers are outside hires who have zero idea what they're doing while not appreciating the people actually working for them. Though I may not agree with unions, they're hard-core union busting.

review_title: Would feel more confident if they could respect labor rights
pros: Food mark out supplements low wages. The health insurance is good, if you can afford it.
cons:
No guaranteed minimum hours, your income depends on if your manager has room for you and all their favorites on the schedule, and Starbucks prefers to test the limits of labor laws in practice and deal with the aftermath rather than just follow the laws as written.

They say the scheduling is flexible for shop employees, but they mean they want you to be flexible. You'll be denied hours if you're not 100% available at all times, then you'll be scheduled for shifts 8 hours apart and told its legal its fine.

review_title: Corporate finds ways to cheat us.
pros: My coworkers and manager are great. Customers usually pretty nice where I live. Overall a pretty good vibe. Benefits are great for only 20 hrs a week. Most managers will work with you when it comes to making sure you can get your ASU degree done.
cons: Pay raise has meant other ways to screw the employees. A lot of locations are having their hours cut, including shift leads. But people who work under 12 hours are effectively fired. Some of the smaller benefits have changed as well. Oh, they're also effectively union-busting without legally falling into that title.

review_title: Corporations don't actually care about you
pros: Benefits. That's it. That's the only good thing.
cons: Bad management. No work life balance. Despite giving more than enough time if/when I called in sick (which was rare) my SM would give me hell about it. I talked to my partners only to find out that he doesn't do that to anyone else. I worked hard, I really cared about my job. I did my best to be helpful and did all the tasks everyone didn't want to do without question, got along with everyone. God forbid I call in when I am actually sick when people have called in for less an hour before their shift. Then my SM had the audacity to go to my best friend who was an ASM to talk crap about me and nitpick everything. He also is gone pretty much every weekend on "vacation" but I can't get vacation to see my parents who live in a different state that I rarely get to see.

job_title: System Analyst II in Seattle, WA
pros: You will have the opportunity to work more as much as you'd like. Assuming you are passionate about what you do each day. Work may not be meaningful though. But work is worship. So if you love it, then it is actually a good thing. I saw my position grow over the years. Love the journey.
cons: Given there is ample amount of work and if you are the passionate one (20% of the people doing 80% of the work), you can easily put in about 50 hrs for each work week. You will run into passively aggressive managers - they have trust issues both in their professional and lives outside of work. The managers use shared mailboxes to snoop into and will effortlessly move work underneath you to the vendor. You will wonder how the work moved somewhere, only to find your own manager moved it. Depending on your style, that may still be okay. You should have a strong passion and desire to work in your inducted role for long periods as they love vendor folks. However will still bring you onboard when they can't bring aboard the vendor folks. As a result, your growth opportunities may be a long haul. Accolades - you may bring appreciations and other good work for yourself back to the team. That may not be enough to move the needle. The senior folks will send note of thanks mostly to each other endlessly. Personal bias - You will be asked to do things a certain way, with no equal consistency thereof required of other team members by the same manager. You may stay on top of your work and put it to closure - only to find out rest of the team does not do so in respective tools and systems, sometimes even leaving the work open ended for years. Manager tech competency - you may wonder on this - depending on if you expected a business / tech / people manager competency of your manager. You will be lucky if your manager has atleast some of these and may be highly deficient in the areas they are responsible for. So that could be a positive or negative depending on how much engagement you though of, to add meaningful value. When the survey comes out, please fill out honestly and not sugar coat it. That does not guarantee outcomes. The organization loves longevity and you should love it as well for yourself and everyone else, to enjoy the ride. Managers circle - Do you enjoy writing notes for your manager connections ? You may have a manager that requires you to write some of these, though you have never had any touchpoint with those connections. So you must genuinely enjoy this.

review_title: Lost all respect for this company
pros: Diverse company, maternity/paternity leave, good teams
cons:
Leadership lacks direction. On the quest for inclusiveness, they have excluded the employee's independent thought and morals with hypocritical decisions that benefit only the company in the end and screws over the employees. It was great 5 years ago, but they have lagged behind in career/salary progression. I can make 50% more at another company doing the exact same thing and without being stretched so thin.
After a bad partner survey, leadership will ask why the score was so low and would want you to tell them why with no anonymity. They lack the empathy to understand why employees feel so frustrated and make you take "life" training. Yes, Starbucks leadership got scammed into hiring Eitan Sharir to teach "Achieving Excellence," forcing Humanist Idealisms down every employee's throat. How's that for diversity and inclusion? 
One of the last things, they got rid of internal promotions! You have to tell your manager you want to apply to another role within the company to advance. And to apply to that role, that role needs to open up first and someone has to step out of it, which is rare. You better hope you get along with your management or find another company.
Leadership also lacks empathy for employee career advancement. They don't ask what employees want to do and what projects they like and just put you where they please. Don't be too surprise they reorg'd and changed your role right after you accepted the job.

APPRECIATING YOUR EMPLOYEES WOULD HELP THEM TO DO THEIR JOB BETTER. * Management tends to be the coolest but they rarely get time with you. * Mostly focused on output and time as opposed to quality. * Say they want you to create authentic customer connections but push for you to try to connect with every customer (even if they don't want to talk to you) and give you crap if you do connect with someone and it takes too long. * Cut hours all the time and say it's happening to everyone when it isn't. cons: Racial Discrimination, as some of you maybe aware Starbucks was recently on the receiving end of a class action lawsuit for discrimination against Asians. I was also bullied so severely by my manager as well as some other baristas that I have had to be in therapy for the past 3 years. Hopefully you are willing to work surprise 13 hour shifts and then be told you aren't a team player or that you don't have enough energy when it's 7pm and you've been in there since 4:30 am and got off 1 am the night before from a deep clean. I later had to request all of my documents and files from Starbucks (a very long process) because I was told when trying to reapply for a part time position that I was basically blacklisted (not actually blacklisted simply put on "hire at your own risk" something like that). Once I got ALL the files they had from me I came to find out that, my former manager; MY WORK PLACE BULLY, cause of my trauma, stress, and anxiety had left a horrible note in my exit interview and basically slandered me and said would not recommend for rehire. They did not have my dozens of incident reports and attempts to file complaints for bullying and such, nor did they have my 2 weeks notice letter that I know I gave in person signed and dated because I have a second copy that I kept for personal records. review_title: In a Different Time, Maybe. But Definitely Not Right Now.
pros:
Good experience with learning how to work effectively in a close knit team
Good job to get experience challenging managerial experience
Good entrance to understanding the inner workings of a business
cons: Right now, between customers, upper management, and even fellow baristas, this position is 8 times harder than before the pandemic. I can't even begin to describe how absolutely overwhelmed I felt keeping the store afloat amid machine breakdowns, aggressive customers, managers who choose favoritism to run the store, and also managers who (when they didn't get the right performance they wanted from their favorites) would push reliable and kind baristas to the brink with the brunt of the work on the floor. I am thoroughly disgusted by how management in my area handled difficult partner to partner situations as well as partner to store manager situations. They have made it abundantly clear that your complaints and feelings will go absolutely nowhere, and at this point its honestly laughable. I cannot stress how somehow, every day I worked there things just got progressively worse and I am so so glad I left and was able to find employment elsewhere. I am actually sad for the co-workers I left behind and I hope they find somewhere else to go.

Cleaning the store including washrooms should be done by another staff and not the ‘baristas.’ In other countries, they have a cleaning staff. The barista title is also a scam. You’re more like all around worker including throwing the trash.

pros: Pay has been fair for the workload, and competitive to those in similar positions. I have liked the long store hours which have allowed for plenty of flexibility in finding work hours as a college student.
cons: As stated on the headline, be careful at which store you work. The location of the store will determine how busy the store will be. My store is located on the boulevard of my city near the freeway, there is a financial plaza, and a few large office buildings. This brings several customers as we happen to be nearby their work or on their way to work. It becomes very hectic and hence the reason you should consider the location. I have been lucky to work at other store locations and feel that the easiest to access, near large streets will be the busiest. One in specific was cafe only, located near government buildings but had a small road up front. It was very slow and calm compared to my fast and hectic store.

review_title: Fun Work if You Like Getting Run Into The Ground
pros: Great benefits (if you can meet the requirements), other partners support and lift you up, tip pool can add additional income, business culture encourages diversity and feeling safe with your identity.
cons: Time on the floor is often understaffed. New managers are "yes men" to upper management, seem to have no care for their partners in many situations. The pay isn't worth the work. I have developed chronic pain from the overwork I've experienced. Tips are often less than $1 an hour for cash tips, and I'll end up with less than a dollar a week in digital tips (added onto paycheck). The customer base is entitled and treats you as less than human. Ruined my morale and burnt me out by expecting me to do tasks above my pay grade while continuously holding out for promised promotions for months. Called in last minute and made to feel guilty for not accepting 8 hour, 4 AM shifts with 10 minutes of notice.
